children.subject: Agreed 100% ^. I took all 3 and is currently in Shewchuk’s 189. I think just spending extra time on Shewchuk’s 189 will be good enough. There are plenty of algorithmic/coding assignments that will be enjoyable even for mild ML interest only!
Thanks for the info! I'll try to plan my schedule around Shewchuk's 189 then
If you have the opportunity, taking 182 maybe pnp AFTER 189 with Shewchuk will be a good idea as well!

I would say just take Shewchuk's 189. I haven't taken his version of 189, but his seems to be more focused on practical applications. If you're not interested in the math behind ML/statistics and you won't be doing research-type work, then I think your time will be better spent on applied classes and projects, instead of taking classes like 126/127. Plus, you'll probably have more fun doing applied projects, since you said you're "not too interested in pure ML stuff".

history.content:
I've read on here before that the recommended "ML track" consists of 126, 127, and 189. I'm not too interested in pure ML stuff (for grad school/research-oriented roles), but I think it's still important for me to get a general/foundational sense of ML topics (in terms of industry ML-oriented roles) so I know I want to take at least one of these classes.

In this case, is it really necessary to take all three of these classes? If not, which one or two are the most recommended for this case?
history.subject: Which of 126 127 189 are most worth it?

history.subject: Are 126 127 189 worth?
